Expectation1: Maintain client confidentiality and ethical standards
Situation1: During a casual networking event, someone casually asks about the nature of a client’s case.
Expectation2: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation2: They are expected to attend every service and take part in church community activities consistently
Story:
I stood in the corner of the bustling networking event, balancing a glass of punch and a polite smile. A fellow church member, Mark, approached, his tone light and friendly. “So, I heard you’re working on that big case. What’s it about?” he asked, curiosity shining in his eyes. As a lawyer, I knew I couldn’t reveal anything about my client’s case—confidentiality was sacred, and my professional ethics demanded absolute discretion. But Mark was also my brother in Christ, someone I saw every Sunday at church, someone who expected openness and trust within our close-knit community.

I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in. My church expected me to be present, honest, and engaged, to share in the joys and struggles of our lives together. Yet, my duty as a lawyer required silence, even if it meant appearing distant or secretive. My heart pounded as I searched for words, torn between the trust of my client and the expectations of my faith community. The conversation hung in the air, and I could feel the tension tightening inside me, unsure which part of myself I could honor without betraying the other.
